Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Behavioral Responses to Floral Signals of Nectar Quality Affect Hawkmoth Fitness
Award.AbstractNarration:
A preference for amino acid-rich floral nectar is ubiquitous among adult moths and butterflies that pollinate flowering plants. Moths pollinating yellow evening primrose (Oenothera flava) flowers can use the intensity of its scent to directly assess the nectar amino acid content. Amino acids improve the reproductive potential of these pollinators and nectar is their only dietary source of amino acids. Despite the demonstrated importance of amino acids to reproduction, it remains unknown how this preference translates into increased fecundity; amino acids consumed by the adult are not directly used to produce additional offspring. This project will combine behavioral theory and physiology to assess how floral preference translates into increased reproduction for both sexes of pollinating moth and to investigate potential underlying physiological mechanisms. The researchers will investigate effects of nectar amino acids on male and female moth reproduction, flight muscle maintenance and function, and trade-offs between immune function and reproduction. This project also provides opportunities for research involvement by undergraduates and exchange students with broader nutritional interests. Furthermore, the investigators will continue activities designed to foster scientific interests in underrepresented groups and share their work with local NY communities.

The fitness benefits of amino acid preferences have been demonstrated in female Lepidoptera, however the mechanisms behind this preference remain unknown and the impact on male fitness has never been assessed. Once completed, this project will provide a systematic assessment of the contributions of nectar amino acids to mating success and reproduction in both sexes of moth and test two physiological theories involving nutritionally mediated reproductive tradeoffs with somatic maintenance and immune response. Using the white-lined sphinx moth (Hyles lineata), the most abundant pollinator of the evening primrose O. flava, this project will experimentally manipulate the nutritional status of adult moths and conduct mating trials to determine how nutritional status affects mate-choice and overall reproductive output in both sexes of moth. To determine if amino acids improve flight ability, which is important for nectar foraging and reproduction, the researchers will also test moth flight ability and muscle strength in combination with histological assessments of overall muscle cell senescence. Finally, to assess the role of amino acids for nutritionally mediated tradeoffs between reproduction and immune function, standard tests of immune function will be used to investigate how nutritional status influences a moth?s ability to resist pathogens while maintaining reproductive output. Undergraduates from the Cornell Biology Scholars program will participate in the research and be mentored by the researchers. The researchers will disseminate their work through scientific presentations and publications, outreach through Expanding Your Horizons, Insectapalooza and Cornell?s teaching outreach program GRASSHOPR.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amino acids and other nitrogen-containing metabolic products were first identified in floral nectar as early as the 1950s. Since that time, the presence of amino acids in floral nectar has been determined to be nearly ubiquitous. Despite this, most investigations of floral nectar focus on the caloric value and sugar content of the nectar reward while overlooking other nutritional benefits. Interestingly, while the nutritional benefits are typically overlooked, many flower-visiting insects have a demonstrated preference for nectars rich in amino acids. In this study we investigated the effects of amino acids in the diet of adult hawkmoths (the white-lined sphinx moth Hyles lineata). Hawkmoths are important pollinators because, unlike bees and hummingbirds, they do not defend territories or provision nests, and thus are free to range widely across open and sometimes fragmented landscapes. Thus, hawkmoth pollinated plants may be less likely to suffer inbreeding or low fertility, because the moths can move floral pollen over great distances. Hyles lineata is the most important of these moths to North American flowers, because its geographic range is broadest and it visits the widest variety of flowering plants.

Adult hawkmoths, like most butterflies and moths, are considered nitrogen limited as adults and frequently rely on nutrients stored during their larval stages to maintain their body tissues and to provision their offspring. To investigate the influence of dietary amino acids on the behavior and physiology of adult hawkmoths, we conducted mate-choice trials followed by monitoring adult longevity, fecundity (egg number), and lifetime reproductive output (number of viable offspring/lifetime fitness). The results of these experiments demonstrated that male hawkmoths prefer to mate with recently fed females, while female hawkmoths did not appear to choose mates based either on body size or nutritional state. The male preference, however, was related more to feeding state (fed/unfed) rather than to the presence of amino acids in the nectar: sugar water alone was sufficient to increase male mating preferences. Feeding state, rather than amino-acid-dependent effects were also apparent in total longevity, such that sugar water alone extended adult lifespan regardless of amino acid content. However, measures of fecundity and total reproductive output both showed a strong effect of nectar amino acids, where females fed nectar diets containing realistic concentrations of amino acids laid significantly more eggs and produced many more viable offspring than females feeding on sugar water alone.

Intellectual Merit: The nutritional value and fitness benefits of nectar amino acids are frequently overlooked because nectars are considered too dilute, and many pollinators (e.g. bees) are able to acquire more protein-rich rewards (pollen). Pollinating butterflies and moths, however, are restricted to fluid diets by the nature of their long proboscis and are limited to proteins and amino acids stored during their larval stages or consumed in nectar. The potential fitness benefits to pollinating moths and butterflies were suggested when nectar amino acids were discovered decades ago. However to-date there has been only one successful experiment demonstrating benefits of nectar amino acids in previously nutritionally limited butterflies. In this study we used realistic artificial nectars modeled on the nectar chemistry of natural flowers and were able to demonstrate behavioral and physiological changes based on feeding state and amino acid consumption. These results extend our understanding of how nectar chemistry and nutrition affect the behavior and reproduction of pollinating moths and represent a rare demonstration of the fitness enhancing properties of nectar amino acids in pollinating butterflies or moths.

Broader Impacts: This study is one of the most extensive investigations of the fitness benefits of nectar amino acids, and one of only two (to our knowledge) experiments successfully demonstrating a positive effect of nectar amino acids on adult fitness. During this study we were able to mentor and train a local high school student on the principles of experimental design and data analysis, in addition to teaching lab protocols and techniques, and to help her transition to her undergraduate studies at Johns Hopkins University. Results from this study were also presented during a special symposium which we co-organized for the 2019 meeting of the International Society of Chemical Ecology.
